channel.title: Intelligence
channel.description: This topic is mostly for discussing intelligence and what it is. To get you guys started here are a few questions. How would you go about measuring intelligence? Can you be wise/knowledgeable without being intelligent and vice versa? How do you recognize intelligence? Can intelligence be the product of hard work or are you born with it or both?

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Tyrone_Chicken Tyrone Chicken
item.description:
@Tyrone_Chicken wrote:

Personally I see intelligence as the ability to learn and your use of the knowledge you have. Knowing a lot adds to the package, but you can know a bunch of useless information and still be an idiot.

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

intelligence to me is being able to utilize the knowledge you possess

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

Bowser jr:

Intelligence without ambition is worthless, so please don’t state that “everyone” would become a genius if they just got the chance. The chance for a new Einstein decreases by every year. The gap of our scientific understanding of the world get more and more complex, too complex for a single man to have an “eureka moment”. Science isn’t driven by people like Einstein alone, it is a gradual process made by all of the world’s scientist.

sadly only several names become synonymous and the rest are left out to hang as though they had contributed nothing unless one delves into deeper studies.

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:54, topic:519605”][quote author=chillwitm888 link=topic=638068.msg4337118#msg4337118 date=1374546762]
Obviously nobody looks up to a mcdonald custodian as an einstein… nope
He isn’t dumb naturally. But viewed by society at his achievements he is a idiotic moron who couldn’t graduate.
Einstein is intelligent because he achieved so much in his life time.
Even ball players like michael jordan. Is he a muscle head? NO
he is a basketball genius.
[/quote]einstein was not intelligent because he accomplished so much. he was intelligent for what he had accomplished. for one, he was a physicist so clearly he had some brains. but he progressed the physics world a great bit with all of his theories and discoveries, his information obtained whilst performing studies and experiments, and his progressment towards nuclear energy and atomic bombs.

however. just because one performs a low-class maintenance job does not mean this person has not obtained a good education. maintenance is well paying for what is required to do (and also depends on where you work)

for example. restaurant maintenance crews won’t make much more, if any, than standard cooks or servers/cashiers/etc. but a regular trashman can make anywhere from 25-40k a year; depending on states. however, working as a trash collector for us postal services can make upwards of 50 and 60k a year.

this isn’t much money to make, but don’t say someone chooses a job because they have no education. some people enjoy doing dirty work and helping people out

also, you cannot be a genius at a sport unless you’re extremely knowledgeable in physics and can literally determine the angle/power/applied forces etc to the situation such as wind in baseball, shot trajectory for basketball and golf etcetc

he’s good at basketball, but is not a genius at it. kthx[/quote]
Wtf, he is a basketball genius. Do you think a super physicist that knows every balls trajectory studied his movements and know momentum on how everything works can beat him?
No. Kthx. This genius can understand every rule and read thousand of books about it.
Can still never even touch Jordan. Jordan is a genius be causes the reaction he imposes when he’s on the field scoring points… Idiot. A pedantic oriented person is only good at one thing, just reading shit and memorizing things.
BY NOW YOU SHOULD KNOW HANDS ON LEARNING IS better than just reading books.
Do you see any true physicist that’s a professional at a sport? Didn’t think so.
Because they aren’t good at sports and won’t ever be.
If someone could truly be at sports because they are good at physics, surely varsity would be a nerdy competition. IT doesn’t work that way!!! THe way he played was his genius side.
NOBODY can emulate it.
I never said Einstein only was intelligent because he accomplished SO MUCH
If you read it was exactly it was. Achievements and accomplishments
His progression in science, math… Progression to nuclear bombs and atomic bombs and theories such as relativity are what he has ACHIEVED which is what I said.
And you are freakin implying you can only be smart if you know physics. No thx
Also I wrote this is how society would view intelligence.
Do people see a garbage collector as a Einstein smart?
Or do they see a professor at MIT teaching thousands of students more Einstein level?
It’s how society sees it.
Yeah kthx

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Fire capez, post:49, topic:519605”]Most kids don’t have exposure to a piano at the age of 5 (I can infer from this that it’s likely he was taught by someone, especially in this time period when a piano would have been extremely expensive, or at least I presume it would be). As for me missing his point I think I might have took a different definition of the word my bad, from google:
sa·vant
/saˈvänt/
Noun
A learned person, esp. a distinguished scientist.

(i thought he was saying a distinguished scientist would disagree with me)[/quote]

The more common term for what I wanted to get across is ‘autistic savant’ or ‘savant syndrome’, more commonly referred to as ‘idiot savant’.

Fire capez:

Huh? If you’re implying that a savant would think I was wrong I would like to see what evidence we have to suggest that natural ability really does exist; if we define natural ability as that which is inherited in terms of physical composition i’m more inclined to agree with you but in respect to cognition unless i’m mistaken there’s no ‘empirical’ proof that intelligence is inherited, and I don’t see how it could be really.

Why would ‘natural ability’ have to be inherited?

I mentioned savants because they generally have what could be considered ‘natural ability’ that wouldn’t necessarily translate from other skills as you seem to imply. Musical savants may not pick up an instrument and be able to play Mozart instantly, and they may need years of training, but musical savants can pick up an instrument and learn to play it proficiently in just a few short years, and most importantly they don’t need formal training. Musical savants also usually have extremely good memory, capable of playing any song they have heard before nearly perfectly, and many musical savants can also play a song nearly perfectly after only hearing it once.

There’s also artistic savants and more notably mathematician savants, who can memorize entire phone books, who can calculate numbers in their heads up to 39 digits, who can do complex math faster than a calculator and sometimes instantly. Sometimes these abilities have to be worked on, but they’re not a case of ‘oh, this person can learn a skill quickly’, millions of young children grow up with musical instruments and millions of children grow up with musicians for parents, millions of young children are taught instruments from a young age. The difference between a savant or a child prodigy to that of a professional adult, is that a savant will be as proficient in a skill as a young child on a similar level to an adult who has been practising that skill their whole life.

Also, as a point of interest, autistic savants usually have a range of conditions ranging from learning difficulties to blindness and deafness, blind musical savants with learning difficulties are particularly common(among savants, that is). In some cases, savant abilities can diminish as the savant ‘learns’ other abilities. There was a case of a young girl who possessed remarkable artistic abilities from an extremely young age, on the level of people like Leonardo da Vinci, but then lost their artistic ability as they learned to talk (or for other reasons, it’s a single case and the reason wasn’t particularly clear).

It’s not like musical savants with learning difficulties can apply their cognitive thinking skills, or mathematical skills, to music, especially when they can play on a professional level before they can speak.

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:51, topic:519605”]Intelligence is different depending on the society.
A society would view intelligence as achievements. Think about it. Albert Einstein is an intelligent man. Because of his theories and his new discoveries… achievements, yes?
I am 100% sure the world isn’t Einstein oriented. Meaning he isn’t the only smart man. There could be people much smarter than he is, however he hasn’t tried to achieve anything. He is your average company worker working under a big named boss and is just typing away or doing what ever he is told by his boss because he has a family to feed or maybe he is worse situation. Facing the world. Because he hasn’t exactly made the right choice. He is a prodigy at school when he was in middle school and elementary… Young entering highschool. Entering at the age of 11 and is now really small.
He gets constantly teased, weakling and a nerd so he decides to fit in and smoke or whatever the bullies of his schools do.
he has taken a iq test before in grade school and got a 197 on iq. He loses it. He is failing all his classes. His parents dont know what to do.
Boom before you know it he is making money from mcdonalds. He is still very good at math.
He is very intelligent but he made the wrong choices. Obviously nobody looks up to a mcdonald custodian as an einstein… nope
He isn’t dumb naturally. But viewed by society at his achievements he is a idiotic moron who couldn’t graduate.
Einstein is intelligent because he achieved so much in his life time.
Even ball players like michael jordan. Is he a muscle head? NO
he is a basketball genius.[/quote]

In the event of one coming into that situation the best possible solution would probably to do what Einstein himself did, work in a patent office (or perhaps a library so you can learn more, basically get yourself from flipping burgers to a job that can you give you more knowledge)

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:48, topic:519605”][quote author=Fire capez link=topic=638068.msg4326549#msg4326549 date=1373024376]

Natural ability doesn’t exist - the reason some people are better then others at things they’ve never studied is due to cognition and retaining of similar situations

Any savant in history would like a word with you.

Huh? If you’re implying that a savant would think I was wrong I would like to see what evidence we have to suggest that natural ability really does exist; if we define natural ability as that which is inherited in terms of physical composition i’m more inclined to agree with you but in respect to cognition unless i’m mistaken there’s no ‘empirical’ proof that intelligence is inherited, and I don’t see how it could be really. It seems much more plausible to me that one could play the piano without playing it before well not because of nature but because they can apply similar methodology (for instance mathematics and knowledge of similar instruments).

I don’t have access to a university institution for academic databases but the below is rather interesting:
http://cogprints.org/656/1/innate.htm
[/quote]
I’m not sure if you missed his point or if he should of said prodigy. Or perhaps people with autism that are considered savants, as that would be maybe not necessarily inherited, but definitely a genetic deformity (again, not sure on my exact wording here with autism). What I believe he is saying is that people seem to either develop innate abilities at extremely young ages that would seem impossible to have developed a skillset to do such activities. You can look at any prodigy and see this. For example Mozart started composing at the age of 5. Most kids can’t even read at the age of 5, yet alone compose a musical piece. How do you propose he developed a set of skills to be able to write musical masterpieces at the age of 5? I find that to be more easily explained as nature rather than nurture, but that is an ongoing argument today. I believe environment does have a major impact on intelligence, but sometimes your genetics can play a major role and you can inherit it.[/quote]

Most kids don’t have exposure to a piano at the age of 5 (I can infer from this that it’s likely he was taught by someone, especially in this time period when a piano would have been extremely expensive, or at least I presume it would be). As for me missing his point I think I might have took a different definition of the word my bad, from google:
sa·vant
/saˈvänt/
Noun
A learned person, esp. a distinguished scientist.

(i thought he was saying a distinguished scientist would disagree with me)

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Fire capez, post:41, topic:519605”][quote author=Niall link=topic=638068.msg4326454#msg4326454 date=1373000922]

Natural ability doesn’t exist - the reason some people are better then others at things they’ve never studied is due to cognition and retaining of similar situations

Any savant in history would like a word with you.
[/quote]

Huh? If you’re implying that a savant would think I was wrong I would like to see what evidence we have to suggest that natural ability really does exist; if we define natural ability as that which is inherited in terms of physical composition i’m more inclined to agree with you but in respect to cognition unless i’m mistaken there’s no ‘empirical’ proof that intelligence is inherited, and I don’t see how it could be really. It seems much more plausible to me that one could play the piano without playing it before well not because of nature but because they can apply similar methodology (for instance mathematics and knowledge of similar instruments).

I don’t have access to a university institution for academic databases but the below is rather interesting:
http://cogprints.org/656/1/innate.htm[/quote]
I’m not sure if you missed his point or if he should of said prodigy. Or perhaps people with autism that are considered savants, as that would be maybe not necessarily inherited, but definitely a genetic deformity (again, not sure on my exact wording here with autism). What I believe he is saying is that people seem to either develop innate abilities at extremely young ages that would seem impossible to have developed a skillset to do such activities. You can look at any prodigy and see this. For example Mozart started composing at the age of 5. Most kids can’t even read at the age of 5, yet alone compose a musical piece. How do you propose he developed a set of skills to be able to write musical masterpieces at the age of 5? I find that to be more easily explained as nature rather than nurture, but that is an ongoing argument today. I believe environment does have a major impact on intelligence, but sometimes your genetics can play a major role and you can inherit it.

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Fire capez, post:46, topic:519605”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=638068.msg4327168#msg4327168 date=1373133657]

Natural ability does exist.

Small example, different ethnicities have slightly different bodies/brains i.e. an obvious one is Chinese people and their eye shape is an example of a large scale natural selection (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection). Natural selection affects humans too just saying. It would be nice if we all held the same value and were just as good as each other but unfortunately we are not (well fortunately we are but on a moral scale it’s an unfortunate thing).

Are you serious? I wasn’t talking about natural selection which is something completely different. And in the future please provide better resources than wikipedia, i’ve provided a link to an academic article which addresses the issue nicely which you obviously didn’t bother to read.

i didn’t read half your post because it’s garbage but k ur correct and im wrong mr smarty pants
[/quote]

This is the intelligent debate section, if you think my post is garbage ignore it, you’re just using that as an excuse because your argument was weak and you’ve been caught out. What about it was garbage, can you not comprehend it?[/quote]
You have caught me out, I can’t comprehend it. Soz bro

Read full topic

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Fire capez link=topic=638068.msg4304029#msg4304029 date=1369476187]Natural ability doesn’t exist - the reason some people are better then others at things they’ve never studied is due to cognition and retaining of similar situations

Any savant in history would like a word with you.[/quote]

Huh? If you’re implying that a savant would think I was wrong I would like to see what evidence we have to suggest that natural ability really does exist; if we define natural ability as that which is inherited in terms of physical composition i’m more inclined to agree with you but in respect to cognition unless i’m mistaken there’s no ‘empirical’ proof that intelligence is inherited, and I don’t see how it could be really. It seems much more plausible to me that one could play the piano without playing it before well not because of nature but because they can apply similar methodology (for instance mathematics and knowledge of similar instruments).

I don’t have access to a university institution for academic databases but the below is rather interesting:
http://cogprints.org/656/1/innate.htm

item.title: Intelligence
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:37, topic:519605”][quote author=MrFun link=topic=638068.msg4313575#msg4313575 date=1371099281]
I believe intelligence is the ability too do something superior then something else such as We humans are intelligence too a bunny because he have built a better shelter, so we don’t get eaten from the wolf
[/quote]
According to Chomsky and other linguists, it’s actually our delayed frontal lobe development that has allowed us to evolved into the “dominant” species. If you think about it, the one characteristic that really separates us from lesser entities is our extensive communication system. Because our brain develops so slowly, we are able to acquire language much better than other species; the period during which learning language is critical in order to become proficient at it is prolonged. It’s interesting how the once inferior rise up to eventually become the dominant.

@topic:

Intelligence <=> aptitude[/quote]

I had this thought the other week I had no idea Chomsky had already beat me to it it makes a lot of sense though.

Read full topic
